physDesc.p: This letter is 3 pages long (seq. 19-21). It is typed on something like notebook paper and words are printed on the page in a slanted manner, with a few words written in the margins in pen. The words "John Gould " are written in pencil across the top of the first page. At the end of the letter, "Margaret Anderson has taken 'Patterns'" is written in pencil. Unsigned.

editorialDecl.p: This letter contains references to the following:

body.p: I am very sorry to hear that your sister is ill. I hope by this time she is ever so much better. Mrs. Russell has been ill; we were afraid of typhoid at one time, but it turned out not to be that, I am thankful to say. She is still in bed with a trained nurse, and our moving to Dublin is postponed. If she is well enough, she will go to Salt Lake City the end of July, as she planned, and once she is gone, I shall go up to Dublin. But at the moment, everything is uncertain.

I am sending you a letter which I received yesterday addressed to you in Richard’s handwriting. He seems to be very much worried lest they conscript him, which would be an awful blow for our cause. He tells me that he and Flint are writing the article for the "Mercure;" and he also tells me that he has written an article on me for "The Egoist," which I think is very nice that they will not come over here; that they cannot, in fact, as he does not believe he could get permission. And I am afraid that may be true.
Did you see "Others?" I have it – a most wretched little paper, at least judging by the first number. I feel rather sorry that I sent them anything; but it cannot be helped now.

Your friend Brown of the Studio Bookshop has been so very nice to me that I took a leaf out of your book and sent him one of my poems, "La Vie de Bohême." I do not think you remember it; it was written about a year ago, and is not one I care much for, but they have accepted it with glee.
You will be amused to hear that the "Century" has taken "The Paper Windmill." I believe they think it is prose and will print is as such, but perhaps that is better than nothing.

"The New Republic" has ordered a sort of boiling down of my Round Table lecture: viz. a fifteen-hundred-word article on "The New Manner in Modern Poetry." I am very much pleased with that. I have sent them your "Clipper Ship" and implored them to take it; but they are so queer that I do not known what they will do. I will let you know as soon as I hear. There is nothing further here. I am going to begin my French translations this week, as they delay makes it impossible for me to wait until I get to Dublin. I am pretty tired as there has been a good deal of anxiety over Mrs. Russell, but I am feeling better now, and hope to get these translations done sometime.
I hope things are looking up with you and that the four-year-old youngster is not too obstreperous.
